title: 1.0 out of 5 stars I cancelled my Amazon prime for good
text: My daughter saved up and bought this and AppleCare coverage. Amazon shipped an iPad out, but it doesn’t match the serial number on the receipt.The iPad cracked, because it’s of low build quality, but Apple can’t do anything because Amazon messed up the serial number (like they’ve apparently done a LOT).Today is my daughter’s 8th birthday, and after WEEKS of trying to get the problem resolved, I just got notice that they won’t do anything for her. They say it’s been too long, that we didn’t notice their problem fast enough, and now when she wakes up I have to tell her and she’s going to cry.I’ll never buy anything from Amazon or Apple again.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars APPLE'S AUTHENTICATION & VERIFICATION PROCESSES HAVE SIMPLY GONE TOO FAR
text: Look, I'm sure this thing is the greatest thing since wheat toast, but we bought several of them recently, and it was a stoned-cold nightmare! Tried to initialize it, couldn't, because Apple required one code after another, sent only to iOS devices (what if you're using Android?), followed by iPad lock-outs, forced time-outs, etc., and then the iPad wouldn't even recognize their own freaking codes! Absolute amateurism! Called Apple Tech Support, only to be told that they had no idea what was wrong. Just a complete freaking joke! You've gotta be outta your freakin' mind to support this company.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Bad Past Experiences with Apple Products
text: Based on the fact that I have an iPad that locked up on a senior and, because she had an obsolete email ID and forgot her password, Apple customer service refused to unlock it: I am not very impressed with the iPad and will be getting a Google Pixel or Amazon Fire for her instead. There are so many better options out there. There's no excuse that we should have to have an expensive piece of equipment like this be locked and worthless after spending hundreds of dollars on it so the company can be rewarded for forcing us to buy another of their products.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Locked Out of Device After Opting Not to Make a Password - Edit - Amazon Support Helped!
text: I thought it would be nice to have a tablet for reading and art, so after some research I found that this iPad would make a really nice combination of both for a pretty reasonable price (especially for apple) I've had many Apple Products: Several iPhones - durability, extended battery life and planned obsolescence obviously annoying but otherwise fine - and one excellent MacBook that lasted me from 2011 to 2022.This item was on the path to being my favorite, until about 4~ish days ago when it decided that I had to put in a passcode to unlock it. For reference - I was asked to do this upon installation, HOWEVER I CHOSE NOT TO DO SO. I understand that means that my information on my iPad was unprotected, but I didn't have any sensitive information on it. The simple solution - give it the good ol' restore via iTunes! Well... It won't connect because I have to put in my non-existent passcode to give my computer access to the device.Oh well! I can always give it a factory reset! Nope. Can't do that. Every time I follow the procedure to do a factory reset, I am locked out of the iPad for EXPPONENTIALLY INCREASING intervals of time.Obviously, I'm annoyed by this. I wanted to see if I could return it and get a new one, so that I can put in a stupid passcode as soon as I set it up, but IN ORDER TO RETURN THE ITEM I NEED TO DO A FACTORY RESET ON IT! Fun fact, that's not possible because every time I follow the procedure for the factory reset, the thing locks me out for longer! So now I have a completely useless iPad. And Amazon support will not assist, and apple will not respond to my inquiries. I hate giving something that has potential to be a good product a bad review, but sadly this one is unusable and I am receiving no assistance. Hopefully nobody else has issues with this kind of thing!Edit: Amazon got in touch with me shortly after review and they offered me a return/refund on the product. Shout out them!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Great while it lasted
text: This iPad died after only five months. Can not get it to turn on. Tried both “forced start” methods with no results. Called Apple support and was told that because it came from Amazon, it did not qualify for expedited replacement. Will have to send it in and wait two to three weeks for repair. Apple rep even said it was probably refurbished, but the invoice says it is new. It was great as long as it worked, thus the review.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Screen resolution is very good
text: Minus: controls on screen too small and hard to hit. No way to make it look like a bigger iPhone, for people with bad eyesight - they just cram more stuff on screen assuming everybody has a magnifier glass handy when using the tablet.Also, icons are too small for the screen size - you get a lot of screen real estate not used around them, with no way to change the distance between icons (to get more icons per screen) or make them bigger.DucDuck and other browsers / apps have control boxes which are too small and not responsive.Plus: worked out of the box, good networking, good audio (especially considering the thickness), good range of accessories available on the net

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good budget choice as the lowest-priced current iPad
text: Does almost everything you want an iPad to do, supports all of the apps that I have seen or used, has a good size screen and supports 1st generation Apple Pencil and bluetooth keyboards if you want these items. Very satisfied. However, note that if you intend to use the iPad for artistic work you may be happier with one that supports the second generation Apple Pencil that has a more "paper-like" feel on the display surface and has a sensor for how much pressure you are putting on the point (the newest USB-C Apple Pencil is not supported on the 9th generation iPad and, by-the-way, the newest. Pencil also does not have pressure sensitivity even on the models that support the second generation Pencil). Other models are smaller, lighter, bigger, and/or faster (e.g., for games or apps like Photoshop) but all of this at added cost.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good value but missing some features
text: The iPad 9th generation offers great value for its price, featuring a powerful A13 Bionic chip that ensures smooth performance in everyday tasks and apps. Its 10.2-inch Retina display delivers crisp visuals, making it perfect for work and entertainment. The addition of iPadOS 15 brings enhanced multitasking capabilities and widgets. While it lacks some premium features like Face ID and the 120Hz ProMotion display, it's a reliable and affordable option for most users. The long battery life and compatibility with the Apple Pencil and Smart Keyboard make it a versatile and accessible tablet.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2023
